name: SUPERHOT
description: SUPERHOT is the first person shooter where time moves only when you move. No regenerating health bars. No conveniently placed ammo drops. It's just you, outnumbered and outgunned, grabbing weapons off fallen enemies to shoot, slice, and maneuver through a hurricane of slow-motion bullets.

Summary: In short, get it if it's on 60% discount or lower. It's a game that is fun for a few hours, but is *vastly* overpriced. They recently announced they will make a SEPARATE game with VR support, despite the original basically being predicated on there being VR support in the future.  Pros: Fun action Interesting concept of time (moves when you do) Some replayability in challenge modes Interesting style  Cons: Story is short and unfulfilling Very expensive for what you get Buggy at times Developers charge an extra $25 for VR support version unless you bought the game BEFORE it was launched, which in my opinion is a total scum move. Developers also promised a 'major update' to the game which never came, instead they launched the 'pay $25 for VR'-version. Massive letdown.  Get it if it's cheap on a sale, otherwise don't bother.

Ehh. For 25 bucks, you get a handful of levels and then another handful to unlock and play in endless mode.  I'm writing this at 2.4 hours played. By the end of that play session, I was pretty much done with SuperHot. The novelty had worn off, the story mode was complete, and none of the extras or replays were going to keep me around.  If you see this game on sale, or get a coupon, I'd say go for it. It's an interesting mechanic to play with. At full price, I'd tell you to save your money. In the meantime, try and track down the original Superhot. It's about the same length, it's free, and I actually preferred the story in that one over this one.  It's not a bad game, and it's a game I can honestly say I enjoyed both times I played it, but it's right on the borderline of things I'd recommend. I don't regret my purchase at full price, but I don't think the average user is going to feel the same way.

Superhot is possibly the most disappointing game I’ve played so far this year. It’s got a great premise with it’s time bending matrix style mechanics, but to be perfectly honest with you that’s all it’s got going for it.  Now for those of you unfamiliar with the title, Superhot is a first person shooter where time moves only as you do… remember those fight sequences in 300… now imagine them with guns and you’ve got superhot – a never before seen melting pot of both strategic and twitch based shooting.   Now of course bullet time isn’t really a new thing and over the years we’ve been inundated with enough Max Payne and F.E.A.R clones to be sick of the concept. However, it’s never really had any use beyond doing John Woo’esque dives to look cool and break up the otherwise monotonous game loop. Heck if you’re name’s Dereck and you enjoy filing tax returns you could probably get through Max Payne without using bullet time once.   The difference with superhot is that the games mechanics actually force you to choreograph some really impressive stunts just to stay alive. It’s a bit like hotline Miami where getting hit once causes instant death forcing the player to make split second decisions to stand a chance in a firefight. Infact it’s a lot like hotline Miami with throwable objects used to stun enemies and block bullets, and very similar melee and projectile weapons.   The only real difference in terms of gameplay is hotline’s top down all-seeing perspective compared with Superhot’s much more limited first person view, a limitation in theory meant to balance out the bullet time… In practice I’ve been shot in the back countless times by enemies behind me. It feels cheap and annoying and it’s one of the major problems I have with the gameplay.   It also feels like the dev’s either didn’t know or didn’t care about this problem when they created their replay system, kilstagram. The idea behind it is that, after you’ve cleared each level, you get to watch a replay of you dispatching your enemies in real time which you get the option to upload to various social media sites. You know because all those nightclub photographs you got tagged in weren’t enough to show people how much fun you were having without them.  Anyway on paper it sounds like a pretty cool idea – the chance for you to show off your Wachowskii’esque bullet time skills but in reality the played back footage looks more like that of a twitchy counterstrike player as you keep glancing behind you to make sure you don’t get flanked causing the camera to spin back and forth making it headache inducing to watch… actually that does sound a lot like a wachowskii film.   Aaaand that’s it… well at least in terms of mechanics… and to be honest with you it all feels very lackluster. For all it borrows from Hotline Miami, I kinda wish they’d taken more. At the moment there simply isn’t any reward for combos or difficult kills like headshots, there isn’t even any music in the background which makes it feel more like an early access title than anything else. But I guess that’s the kind of aesthetic they were going for – everything in the game is made up of plain textures with a really minimalist color scheme. And it also ties in with the story the dev’s wanted to tell… that’s right the dev’s actually managed to come up with a story to tie all of this together, though as you’ll see it’s so phoned in and half-arsed it feels more like it’s there for the sake of having a story.   Remember Pony island? Good Neither does the guy that wrote this drivel. Instead of being a story within Superhot’s universe, it’s a story about playing superhot. You start off the game looking at a dos style operating system when suddenly you get an instant message from a friend sending you a file titled “superhot.exe”. After playing a few levels, the system detects you and it pans out exactly as you’d expect it to be with the system trying to stop the player and the player finding loopholes and backdoor routes to evade the system. The problem with the narrative is that it does not compliment the gameplay – you could replace the shooting segments with Tetris and the story would still work.  It’s a prime example of what people who like to use big words to sound clever call Ludonarative Dissonance, where the gameplay and story don’t match and the exposition just feels like a hindrance to the actual meat of the game.  Whilst I can kind of get over the mediocre storyline, the thing I find unforgivable is the 2-hour campaign length. That’s right, you can beat the game in a single sitting! Now I’m not saying all short games are bad, in fact titles like Portal have been praised for not overstaying their welcome with their shot length. The problem with Superhot being so short is that instead of leaving me wanting more, I just feel unsatisfied by the finished product.   To rub it in, the dev’s have had a working prototype since 2013 which featured quite a few of the levels that ended up in the full game, most of which was made in a few days at a game jam. It can’t be so hard to make a level that the team could only pump out 20 or so short levels in 3 years! Especially with backing and e3 coverage by both Sony and Microsoft. To have the balls to demand 17 quid (that’s the equivalent of 3 copies of Undertale) for a game that can be beaten in an afternoon is a little bit insulting. Granted there’s more to it than just the campaign, there’s also the arena mode where you have to fend off endless waves of enemies which gets boring after about an hour and there’s the challenge mode where you’ll have to play the campaign meeting certain conditions (for example only using the katana). Like the story, both these additional modes feel last minute and tacked on.   The best analogy I have for the game as a whole is to imagine the first chapter of id software’s doom being sold full price. Back in its heyday in the 90’s nobody had ever seen anything like DOOM and I can safely say the gameplay of superhot is just as innovative. However, whilst the game that’s there is relatively enjoyable, albeit flawed, it just ends before the more interesting experimental stages (like in the 3rd act of doom) get to be shown. Ultimately I can’t really recommend picking up the game unless it’s heavily discounted and, to go with the analogy, the game receives a John Romero out of 10. It showed a lot of promise in it’s early days as a prototype, started getting full of itself at e3 and then ultimately ♥♥♥♥ the bed with one fell daikatanaesque swoop.

SUPER HOT  Superhot is a first person shooter, where time only moves when you move. This game offers you 3 gamemodes: the main story, endless mode and challenge mode. They all have one thing in common, you have to kill red dudes. To kill red dudes you can use your fists, pistol, katana, shotgun, rifle and you can also throw stuff at them to kill them. Main story is pretty short, took me about 4 hours to complete. Even though main story is pretty short it offers you really well made story and some nice plots. In endless mode you can play in different levels and you have to kill red dudes as long as you can survive. In challenge mode you are given a mission, for example kill 2 red dudes with katana. This time moves only when you move is really nice concept and it works well in this case.  My rating for this game 9,5/10

Imagine if you will: Wait, what was I talking about?   SUPER HOT SUPER  HOT SUPER... HOT....  Imagine, if you will, a simulator where everything is in slow motion. Then imagine that when you move, the rest of the world moves. Granted, if you don't move at all things are still moving, but very slowly. So slow, in fact, that you can potentially dodge bullets, cut enemies to shreds before they can move, toss guns into the face of oncoming attackers and pick up their weapon in mid-air and shoot them with it... all before the guy behind them even has a chance to aim at you. But, take a step without being aware or look around too much, and you'll likely end up getting clobbered from a direction you didn't even know was a threat.  This game is great on so many different levels that it's really hard to cover everything. I was a kickstarter backer and have played the game on various levels of completion and none of it was ever enough to quench my curiousity about the plot and, of course, the gameplay.   You basically have hundreds of ways to play through each level. Choose to go at it fisticuffs for some additional challenge or destroy everyone with headshots. Just about any way you can figure it out, that's going to work. Except, of course, the ways it won't. Which, you'll find out later in the game, become pretty linear... brutally so. However, keeping your wits about you can get you through most levels without even a retry.  And... visit the chatroom (GGchat). There is more going on there that there appears to be at first... including some hints for different levels.  I definitely recommend this game for anyone that has a computer!  And, don't forget... SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT!

SUPERHOT Review    PLOT   Basically you're a dude on his computer talking to one of his online friends who sends him a cracked file for 'superhot.exe' which is described as 'a tool' by a company the game is being controlled by. Matrix-Inception ♥♥♥♥ happens and you get brainwashed. I would add extra info but I don't want to spoil it.   GAMEPLAY   Not inculding the massive ammounts of secrets and extra stuff to look at in the menus (including 'the game of life' and other retro computer things), the game basically focuses on the player who is trying to eliminate all of the 'red dudes' in each level using a variety of melee and ranged weapons. The main gimmick is that the level (including enemies and flying objects) only move at the same speed the player is moving at. The game is actually extremely fast-paced, which can be seen in the replays after a level, but what would be extreme difficulty and a need for inhuman reflexes is solved by the slowing mechanic, making you seem like a ♥♥♥♥ing ninja at the normal speed (so much so that they have a website just for uploading replays).   PROS    -Smooth mechanics -Insane visuals (especially in cinematics) -Developer support  -(limited) VR support -Full controller support -Nice arsenal of weapons -Hard but fair (mostly) -4th wall breaks that play in with the story -Fun overall   CONS   -Minimal enemy noise for footsteps and other motions (expect to be screwed over quite a bit) -Story could be a little less cryptic -Short (I have no issues with the length due to the tons of extra tidbits and gamemodes to do, but it is a major problem with some people) [See 'OUTDATED ISSUES'] -You have to be looking directly at an enemy to melee  -Minimum distance to body switch is tricky -Can get repetitive -Overpriced at the moment   OUTDATED ISSUES   -Lots of people have been talking about the fact that you can't see your replay without 'SUPER HOT' flashing in your screen, but pressing f5 gets rid of it, and there are lots of playback options to use with a numpad. If this has been here the whole time I don't understand what people are whining about. (BTW fn+f5 or fn+alt+f5 to do it on Mac)  -Everyone has been talking about the length of the game, but the developers have recently announced a free DLC which includes extra levels, procedural generation, skill-based powerups, and other goodies which are being said to drastically increase the playtime of the game.

[Encourage Memes]  I HAVE MIXED FEELINGS ABOUT SUPER HOT.  It's an intro in TO cyberpunk. It gives players of any skill level a unique action-puzzle experience that ends up being a blend of The Matrix meets MKultra if M.K. stood for Manchurian Killer.  It's better as an arcade game, and you'll unlock that mode following the completion of the short story campaign. I thought it was a tensionless, droll experience up until about the point where the story began to end, when the levels become much more difficult (when it became fun).  There's a lot to get into in too many words, so here was my experience.   Spoilers will not be tagged, but I'll try to avoid blatantly spelling it out.  Super Hot is all about glamour and if you're a playful gamer, you'll have plenty to do. The campaign is presented very well, but I always felt three steps ahead of the cyberpunk story. It ended at about the point where I thought it should've continued on, but damn it was it ever presented in a visually exciting way. I went on to discover all the game's secrets and that's where the story started to really lose me.  'You aren't actually going to reveal anything, I get it, Super Hot.' And then Super Hot's mysterious Red Voice continued on and on with its attitude. I continued to find the secrets because it did answer some of its questions, only for it to conclude with a reward for my dedication, and while I appreciate that it fits back in with the hypnosis/brainwashing angle, I felt as insulted by the game as if it asked me if I wanted to buy more energy, like a freemium game would. The 'secrets' were ultimately unecessary, since like I said, the majority of the ''secret'' ''''answers'''' were questions that I'm confident most players solved themselves in the campaign.  What a strange path the story took though. I was really into it up until the point where it was clear that the secrets were bunk, and then it got all capitalist on me and threw the punk part of the cyberpunk out the window with the coupon.  Still, tho, the game's themes and presentation are intertwined, and I actually do like Killstagram because it ties back into the boldness of their compulsion to make you part of their viral marketing, and even the warez angle feeds into the viral edginess. That stuff is fantastic. Moreover, Killstagram feeds into the playfulness and how much fun you can have by learning that juggling guns and banking thrown objects off walls is the most hilarious and cool looking fun you can have. Killstagram, if you're into it, changes the way you approach the game, turning it into something more creative than clearing the mission.  The story is an intro to cyberpunk and posthuman themes though, and its style and tone are its own. I just wish they excluded the 'secrets' which ruined it pretty handily.  So, yes. It's true. The game really starts after the campaign ends. This game is so much more engaging as an arcade game with rules and restrictions. The puzzle aspect really shines when the game becomes challenging, forcing you to think creatively, and even reactively...  So yeah, I keep bouncing back and forth on whether or not this game is Super Hot or Over Rated because I keep thinking back to the F.E.A.R. series as one of the big games to use slo-mo in a glamorous way but I think you'll probably enjoy the game of Super Hot, and if you didn't find it very challenging, keep playing and the intensity will increase through later modes.

I don't really write reviews for games but I feel like I should write one for this, specifically since it is in Early Access.  Yes, the story is very short, unfortunately. I completed it in about 2 hours, with messing around in the campaign (Trying dumb stuff, no slow mo, etc). While it is a pretty dark and good story (If you want to call it a story, more like a stretched plotline to a story), there really isn't much to it.  After beating the story you get Challenge Mode, and Endless Mode. Challenge Mode being the single player campaign with certain restrictions or objectives to meet, Endless Mode being exactly that. endless enemies spawning in an arena. The more you play, the more arenas you unlock. It can get boring after a while but I can see myself always coming back for at least a little fun for quite some time in the future.  The game itself, however, is fantastic. It even came with it's own website, where you can upload your own clips and replays. While even that may not be handling all the traffic it's been getting, not many games have that. I do wish there were more edit options, however.  Time moving only when you move is a great concept. Any action, even rotating, allows things to move. You can chain together kills in a very satisfying way and put together combos that make you look like you've played shooters every day for your entire life. The game flows extremely smooth and I can't help but say the only reason it wasn't worth the 20 dollars is because the story is so short. But I'm sure more content will be added in future patches, so eventually it will be worth the 20. 15? Sure, but personally I think 10 is too low.   With the popularity this has gotten in only a few days time, there is bound to be more content added (hopefully some *background music*) and eventually, I would hope, mod support. Community levels I would imagine is the minimum that will come into play.  Play this game, tell people to play this game, share it with your friends. But don't talk too much about it, don't let them know what the system is about.

TL;DR: If scoring and challenges are for you, then you will love SUPERHOT, otherwise you will be sorely disappointed.  I was skeptical about this at first after seeing an abundance of negative reviews about the length of SUPERHOT, but I gave it a shot after a friend's recommendation. The extended hours of fun come from completing the challenge levels (katana-only, fists-only, fullstop, real-time, etc.) and going for speed records (speed run challenges). You will often find games like this in the following categories: shumps/shooting games, so-called rogue likes, and indie platformers. As an aside, I saw similar negative reviews for 'House of the Dying Sun,' a tactics/space FPS game, criticizing the length, but neglecting the challenges.  SUPERHOT is graphically simple, which helps to make important things pop out (enemies, bullets, and weapons), but is stylish enough to be interesting to look at.  Sound is slowed down with time, which provides an indicator of enemies and bullets outside of your view. The glass shattering sounds are fairly satisfying as well.  Overall, I enjoy this simple yet challenging game.

Fantastically polished game, SUPERHOT takes the prototype and does an excellent job of developing the mechanics in to a finalised product that's worth every penny.  SUPERHOT has a very simple ruleset, and equally simple (but effective) visuals to accommodate that. As a result it's always very clear what you're supposed to be doing. While it is an FPS game, the core mechanic turns it in to something much more strategy-based, especially when attempting the challenge modes.  The main criticism people have with the game is that it's too short, and that's true if you ignore all the extra content that comes after completing the story mode. If you're somebody that enjoys challenging yourself, then you'll have many hours of fun with the challenge modes, in that respect the story mode is more like a long tutorial.  My only personal gripe is that the boss character featured in the prototype didn't make an appearance, but understandably they decided to take the game in a different direction.  In short, if you like the look of this and you understand that the story mode is only a small portion of the game, then I absolutely recommend it.

There's likely some community based ARG that helps unveil 'THE TRUE STORY' but I don't know. I guess if you're into that then this is for you. To me it just seems like they're deceiving customers into being okay with any kind of quality gameplay running dry after only a couple hours. Obligatory line: This is the most innovative shooter I've played in years!  There, now that I've done as the game clearly orders me to (literally), I can get to the actual review.  SUPERHOT (no, I dont know why it's always capitalized, just roll with it) is basically 'Bullet Time: The Game'. The core mechanic is that time only moves when you do. When you're just turning your view around, it'll move kinda slowly, but when you're actually MOVING, it'll be real-time. But the instant you stop... back to time-stop. When combined with the fact that bullets dont move at the speed they do IRL... and are slowed down just enough that even in real-time, you can follow their path (they are still very quick though), you can watch enemy shots, and dodge out of the way, just like in the Matrix! But if that were the only mechanic this offered, it wouldnt be nearly as interesting.  Needless to say, the other core mechanic is, well, the weapons. There are only a few of these... pistol, shotgun, machinegun, katana, bat. Not much, you say? Believe me, it's enough. Learning all of the properties of these weapons is key, not just for using them yourself, but for dealing with enemies. With the game's bright, stark graphics, it's super easy to see at a glance what each enemy is carrying, and plan accordingly. But shooting and slashing isnt your only trick. You can also fling weapons or objects at enemies; hit them with one, and they'll be stunned, and their weapon will go flying... and you can grab it right out of the air, if you are in position. Then let 'em have it! Just as fun as it sounds.   That's not all though: The game's other mechanic is the HotSwitch, the ability to instantly, and from any distance, switch into the body of any enemy you can see. Did a guy with a shotgun just fire an unavoidable wall of bullets at you? Take him over before they hit. The only downside is that when you take someone over, the weapon they are holding will break; but you can bypass this by smacking them with an object so they drop it, taking them over, and then grabbing the gun that'll be hanging in the air right next to you.  Oh, and you can slash, or even SHOOT, enemy bullets out of the air.  Combine all of these things, and, well... it cant get much more awesome than this.  Be warned though: This is NOT a story-focused game. Oh, it has one, and it's interesting, but it's very short. This is more of an arcade-style score-attack game, as the meat of the game's content... and there's alot of it... is in the 'endless' mode. Dont think this makes the game not worth the cost though, because it is.  Also: This game is HARD. You're going to die. A lot. Enemies are extremely numerous, fast, aggressive, smart, and can grab weapons off of the ground. And you have to really pay attention, as they just... keep... coming. You have to constantly check the doors for the tell-tale red glow that signifies an enemy about to spawn from one (and they can act *instantly* after they spawn, so dont think you have a safe moment while they're doing so!). But this just makes all of your awesome actions even more amazing, when you're successful against them. But yeah, if you're after a challenge... you'll find it here.  Really, I cant recommend this one enough. An FPS that rewards careful, tactical play, yet still requires LOTS of real skill to do well in, with awesome mechanics that let you do ridiculously awesome moves, and never any true unfairness... really, it doesnt get much better than this. I'll be playing this one alot, myself.  Oh, and one more thing: After any run, you can view, edit, and even upload a real-time replay of everything that just happened. I honestly just never get tired of watching these.

So, after a few years in development, SUPERHOT finally graces our steam libraries. But is it any good?   Perhaps not.   It most certainly is.   Story  Odd of me to start with the story for a game that doesn't seem to have any story in it, at first, then it starts having a story and becomes   unsettingly meta   a tale about our existence and how fragile our weak, pitiful bodies are and   it really isn't all that great to be honest, just merely an excuse plot to shoot red dudes in the face   SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT.    It also tries to be meta but ends up playing it too much. I was irritated by it in the end when it got blatantly meta.   SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT  TL;DR -   Nothing much to write home about.   SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT   Gameplay  It's a first person shooter that plays like a puzzle. What's the best way to deal with a bunch of red dudes hellbent on killing you? The methods vary from level to level, whether that be shooting them in the face with a pistol, blowing them away with a shotgun, or just punching them in the face. Time moves when you move, the game will boldly state, which is true, time does move when you do, and standing still causes time to move very slowly, looking around causes the game to speed up a little, and moving accelerates the game full-force. You have these tools and the weapons scattered about each map to solve the puzzle which culminates in 'kill all the red dudes and you win'.    Later on, you get the ability to swap bodies at will, like a ghost.   I find the gameplay to be an interesting concept. And it does tend to get needlessly difficult at times and moments where you'll die instantly if you don't move as soon as possible can be frustrating, it's best to carry some patience with you, it's not Super Meat Boy levels of frustration but it can be frustrating at some parts.    Unfortunately, the game doesn't carry itself very well when you complete the game, unlocking endless mode and challenges, playing those will only get you so far. It's a neat little timewaster though.    TL;DR - TIME. MOVES. WHEN. YOU. MOVE. That's the gimmick and it does it well, you can throw, punch, jump, shoot, anything to kill the red dudes. Frustrating at times.   Graphics  Simplistic. The geometry is all white with some exceptions of black being used to mark out objects that can be picked up. Enemies (and yourself) are red and look like something from a wireframe. It works, though, for the most part, you are in a   simulation of sorts   SUPER HOT immersive innovative video game.  TL;DR - Simplistic, but it works.   Sound/Music  There really isn't all that much in this game to be honest when it comes to sound and music, music, when it comes up, is okay at best, and you're not going to hear much sound from the game outside of the computer interface and, in-game, the shooting and glass breaking.  TL;DR - Not much to write home about.   Ending Statement  SUPERHOT is, as they say, an innovative shooter, it's   not   THE most innovative shooter I've played but it certainly carries some interesting gimmicks. Purely good as a timewaster but the price tag might be a bit much for what's in it.  In the end, I'm going to  recommend  this game but  preferably get it during a sale or with a severe discount .

This game is just about flawless. You're given a really unique, cool, but easy to understand concept, and the game just goes with it. You make a hectic, spur-of-the-moment action scene, but you're doing it so deliberately, and the game rewards you for planning, being fast, and playing smart rather than pure mechanical skill. Tight controls, satisfying AI, good level design, the graphic design and user interfaces are unique and really work. The story is the type that can only be told within a video game, and for a game about killing red dudes it's actually pretty good, especially because it has tiny amounts of narrative and dialogue. Plus the challenges and endless modes are where you'll get a lot of mileage from.  It's a game I haven't really seen since Hotline Miami. Here is a level full of dudes and weapons, you and the dudes die in one hit, go nuts. You have a similar action flow (knock Dude 1 down, steal his gun, shoot Dude 2, throw gun to stun Dude 3, steal Dude 3's katana, chop up Dude 1 before he even stood up, throw katana at Dude 3, hotswitch into Dude 3, grab katana midair, impale Dude 4 with aimed katana throw), but unlike Hotline Miami the game makes it feel so natural, planned out, and deliberate until you watch the last minute-and-a-half of action compressed into ten real-time seconds of straight up dude killin'. It's good, it's really good, it feels satisfying to pull off, and it looks impressive too. Most of your deaths and failures are preventable with proper time/resource management, not like Hotline Miami where your deaths are funky hitreg or not being able to see a gunman a mile away.   I can easily see this game on a bunch of GOTY lists, but at $25 I don't think it's worth it. At least, not for everyone. If this game was $10-15 I'd heartily recommend it, but when there are other titles on Steam that are just as (if not more) innovative and unique, for half the price, and with more content. The gameplay's solid like you wouldn't believe, but I beat the campaign in an hour and a half, and the challenge/endless modes are just alterations on levels in the campaign. Only one enemy type, 3 guns, 2 types of melees, so far no promises on adding extra content, developer or usermade. Can the gameplay support the price? I think so, but I don't think most people can agree.  I suggest buying it on sale. At worst, you can buy the game, beat the campaign, and refund it and still be ~20 minutes under the time requirement to return it.

SUPERHOT: the only game in the history of all videogames that uses the classic 'slow and speed up time' concept in a way that is truly intuitive, challenging, and fun. Is this a sign of the End Times? Probably.

SUPERHOT has a really cool mechanic where time only moves if you move. This turns what would be an ordinary shooter into a really cool tactical simulator (almost). And at the end of every level, or when you die, it shows the real-time footage of your actions and you can see all the cool kills you got.  The story mode is SUPERSHORT, but luckily there's tons of unlockable challenge modes and endless modes. Kind of disappointing is that I haven't found any of the cheat modes that were in the beta. Maybe they'll be patched in, in the future.  The biggest let-down is the optimization. For a game of this scope you don't really need tons of graphics settings, but for my system (which runs the newest games on close to max settings) I had to turn everything to the lowest settings in order to get -relatively- smooth gameplay. That being said, the visual style isn't really focused on amazing graphics to begin with, so running on minimum doesn't hurt what this game has achieved; a really cool shooter.

So the basic concept is time pratically stands still until you start moving. Tiny movements (such as turning your head) speed time up slightly while big movements (such as walking) speed time up to regular speed. I would honestly say this is almost more puzzle than FPS similarly to how some stealth games are more puzzler than it is an FPS or third person shooter. This game has tons of replayablitity because there are a ton of modes/challenges that you can unlock after finishing the story. Ok folks, here's the deal. If its on sale, go for it. If you pay $30, you are going to be disappointed. Most of the bad reviews I've read seem to be from a position of overpriced instead of not being fun. I love it.  First of all, time never stands still (except in one challenge mode.) Time always churns at a snail pace and the more character movement you have, the more time speeds up to normal. So when you move your mouse around, you are moving and time does speed up. Some people call this a super annoying flaw. We call those people ♥♥♥♥♥ gamers. But before I digress...  There are no graphics to speak of. The lackluster screenshots do it accurate justice. It is not a beautiful game by any stretch. For what the game is, however, they work. The stark contrasts and geometric simplicity are kind of refreshing when many games over-saturate backgrounds. It started as a design constraint and turned into a legitamate style.   The gameplay is hectic. And loads of fun. I will say there exist ways to exploit the AI, which I have used to my advantage more than once. You hide behind a corner and run into the wall until someone comes. Then you clober them.  There really isnt a story to the game. Something about a hacker game that sucks people into the computer and turns them into hitmen or something. I dunno. You really don't need it though. The main 'campaign' doesn't take exceptionally long to beat, but it does unlock endless mode. And at heart this is an arcade style game.   Once I stopped trying to 'win,' I began to have massive amounts of fun just trying to pull off ridiculous feats and failing over and over and over (there are no load times btw.) Its when you pull off a brutal combo thats fluid and technically magnificent, you can get a lot of satisfaction seeing it replayed at regular time.   Pros -Insanely fun -No load times -Lots of replayability -You can cut bullets with a sword  Cons -If you pay more than $15 you are overpaying. -No modability in a platform that begs for it. -'Graphics suck' if thats your position on things. (Trying to be unbiased here)  Bottom Line: 6/10 If the regular price were $15 bucks I would bump it up to a seven. Its loads of fun, but I would like to see more done with it before it deserves a higher score.
